From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
Subject: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=211599040; y=AUeLhTLCFqHoW_Q4bKy65fD3BuEoPsPRbkBENFRNvw7vE8F-9zyh
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

Hello all-

Does crossover do anything in PNEAT and HyperNEAT?

PNEAT:
If I am reading the code correctly, during crossover, if the substrates are
the same (i.e. all links have the same ID), which is always the case in
P-NEAT, *all* of the link values are taken from either parent1 or parent2.
Isn't it more normal when crossing over to take some from parent1 and some
from parent2? Why grab all from just one?

This means that in PNEAT crossover does nothing, right? It will always grab
the substrate of parent1 or the substrate of parent2.  If I track parent and
offspring fitness, 100% of the time the child has the exact same fitness as
one of the two parents.

On to HyperNEAT:

I tracked the fitness of each parent and the resulting offspring. The odd
thing is that the organisms that are crossed only (i.e. they are never
mutated) have the *exact* same fitness of one of their parents 98.88% of the
time. In 20 runs, that was only 136 orgs out of 12257 that were crossed over
and not mutated. That seems wrong, doesn't it? Why would these new links
have such a small impact? It turns out that this is because nearly every
time that there is an extra link that gets placed in the child, the parent
that donated that link is also the parent whose weights are being grabbed,
meaning that the crossover is only copying the parent (hence the same
fitness). It seems to me that crossover should be much more disruptive, no?


As a final test, I did a set of hyperneat and pneat runs with the default
'MutateOnlyProbability' parameter set to .25, so 25% of orgs never are
candidates for crossover. I then ran experimental treatments
hyperneat-noCross and pneat-noCross where the MutateOnlyProbability
parameter was set to 1, so no orgs were crossed over. Despite my comments
above, Hyperneat (with cross) did beat HyperNEAT-noCross, however the
difference was not tremendous (although it does seem to be statistically
significant). For p-neat, the reverse was true. Nevertheless, this is not a
perfect test of whether crossover pays dividends, because if crossover does
nothing most of the time, and I increase MutateOnlyProbability from .25 to
1, I have effectively raised the mutation rate (only 80% of crossed orgs are
also mutated).

Are these the intended consequences of crossover, or am I missing something?

Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...
